title: SB 1159
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to make cost, quality, and equity data available to promote innovative healthcare approaches in California. A data atlas will be used to assess healthcare needs, resources, and control costs. The California Legislature aims to assess healthcare needs, control costs, improve quality, address disparities, increase transparency, promote innovative programs, and encourage efficient utilization of prescription drugs and technology. The California Legislature aims to assess healthcare needs, control costs, improve quality, address disparities, increase transparency, and promote innovative programs. Additionally, they encourage efficient utilization of prescription drugs and technology, reduce unnecessary healthcare, and educate consumers on healthcare information. Chapter 8 of the Health and Safety Code is repealed and replaced with the California Health Care Cost, Quality, and Equity Data Atlas. Chapter 8 (Section 127670) of the Health and Safety Code introduces the California Health Care Cost, Quality, and Equity Data Atlas. The California Health and Human Services Agency is tasked with researching options for developing this atlas in line with specified requirements. Identification of key data submitters for the California Health Care Cost, Quality, and Equity Data Atlas includes health care service plans, insurers, suppliers, providers, self-insured employers, multiemployer self-insured plans, and trust administrators. A comparative analysis of potential models used in other states for the California Health Care Cost, Quality, and Equity Data Atlas includes data from health care service plans, insurers, and providers' claims data. Pricing information for health care items, services, and medical and surgical episodes of care is gathered from allowed charges for covered health care items and services to enable meaningful comparisons of provider prices and treatment costs. The curr_chunk discusses the importance of including information on social determinants of health and clinical data from various healthcare providers for data submission. This data includes factors such as age, gender, race, ethnicity, and ZIP Code. The curr_chunk provides recommendations on governance structures and funding approaches for the cost, quality, and equity data atlas, including representatives of health care stakeholders and experts. Recommendations on potential funding approaches for the cost, quality, and equity data atlas, assessing development options and consulting with various healthcare stakeholders and experts. The agency will consult with healthcare stakeholders and experts, including purchasers, to conduct research and make results available to the public by March 1, 2017. Federal funds may be used for this purpose.
